sc2Lecture.text: Every body paragraph opens with a claim.

bodyPairs.keyExpr: the main advantage of limiting phones is
bodyPairs.rest: that students can focus better in class. This is because phones are full of apps that keep interrupting you. As a result, schools that ban phones have seen big improvements in students' results.
bodyPairs.note: Claim ‚Üí Reason ‚Üí Result. Three sentences is enough.

bodyPairs.keyExpr: one key problem with too much phone use is
bodyPairs.rest: the damage it does to sleep. Looking at a bright screen late at night makes it harder to fall asleep. Consequently, tired students find it much more difficult to learn.

bodyPairs.opinion: as far as I am concerned,
bodyPairs.keyExpr: one problem that is often forgotten is
bodyPairs.rest: the effect on social skills. When young people are always on their phones, they get less practice at talking face to face. Therefore, they may find real conversations more difficult as they get older.
bodyPairs.note: This is YOUR idea ‚Äî not from the question. Required for full marks.
bodyPairs.ownIdeaNarration: And now ‚Äî your own idea. This one is yours.

conclNarrations: Restate your opinion ‚Äî but never repeat the same words.
Echo your two main points briefly.
Then rephrase your position in one clear sentence.
And close with a final verdict. Short. Confident. Done.

conclData.text: In conclusion, I firmly believe that the question of phone use for young people requires careful thought.
On one hand, limiting phones leads to better focus, better sleep, and better wellbeing.
On the other hand, smartphones have real benefits and should not be seen as purely harmful.
In other words, it is not the phone itself that is the problem ‚Äî it is how and when it is used.
Overall, a balanced approach to limiting smartphone use would benefit most young people.
